conclusion: The problem involves analyzing changes in shadows (A, B, C, D) when the light source moves to the right above the objects.

The image shows four objects: a circular tart (casting shadow A), a cylindrical object with a card on top (casting shadow B), a soccer ball (casting shadow C), and a rolled-up cylindrical object (casting shadow D).
When the light source moves to the right above the objects, the shadows will shift towards the left because the light source is now coming from the right.

The size of the shadows will depend on the angle of the light source relative to the objects. If the light source is directly above the objects, the shadows will be smaller and more concentrated. If the light source is at an angle, the shadows will be elongated and larger.

The shapes of the shadows will change based on the orientation of the objects and the direction of the light. For example, a spherical object like a soccer ball will cast a circular shadow directly below it if the light is directly overhead, but the shadow will elongate if the light is at an angle.
Objects closer to the light source will have larger shadows compared to those farther away, assuming all objects are on the same plane.
Identify the new position of the light source (to the right above the objects).
Determine the direction of the shadows based on the light's position (shadows will move left).
Assess the size of the shadows based on the angle and distance of the light source (shadows may become larger if the light is at an angle).
Consider the shape of the objects and how their shadows will change with the light's new position (e.g., spherical objects may have elongated shadows).
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move to the left.
The size of the shadows may increase if the light source is at an angle.
The shape of the shadows will change based on the object's geometry and the light's angle.
